chapter.title: &susemgr; &productnumber3; Proxy
chapter.para: This guide explains how to install and set up &susemgr; &productnumber3; Proxy.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: &susemgr; &productnumber3; Proxy is a &susemgr; add-on that caches software packages on an internal, central server. The proxy caches patch updates from &suse; or custom RPMs generated by third-party organizations. A proxy allows you to use bandwidth more effectively because client systems connect to the proxy for updates, and the &susemgr; server is no longer required to handle all client requests. The proxy also supports transparent custom package deployment.
&susemgr; Proxy is an open source (GPLv2) solution that provides the following features:

listitem.para: Cache software packages within a Squid proxy.
Client systems see the &susemgrproxy; as a &susemgr; server instance.
The &susemgrproxy; is registered as a client system with the &susemgr; server.

sect1.para: The primary goal of a &susemgrproxy; is to improve &susemgr; performance by reducing bandwidth requirements and accelerating response time.

sect1.title: Installation and Setup
sect1.para: The following section will guide you through the installation and setup procedure.

important.title: Registering Proxies
important.para: &susemgr; Proxy systems are registered as traditional systems using a bootstrap script. Currently there is no method to register proxy systems using Salt. A SUSE Manager Proxy can serve both Traditional and Salt clients.

step.para: Create an activation key based on the &sle; 12 SP2 base channel and ensure you have selected the child SUSE Manager Proxy channel which is required for providing the proxy packages. See .
Modify a bootstrap script for the proxy and register it with &susemgr; using the new activation key. See .
Once you have registered your client, direct your browser to the &susemgr; &webui; and login.
Select the Systems tab and click on your newly registered &sle; 12 SP2 client system from the Systems Overview table.
On the system's detail page select the Software tab, then Software Channels tab.

You will see a list of channels to which your client is already subscribed to. Select the two unchecked proxy channels which include the SUSE Manager Proxy-3.0-Pool and SUSE-Manager-Proxy-3.0-Updates, then select Change Subscriptions to continue. This will provide the required repositories for the proxy packages from the &susemgr; Server to the client.
Select the Software, Packages tab and then Install New Packages.
Type patterns within the search field on the Installable Packages page. Select the Proxy pattern and then select Install Selected Packages.
On the Confirm Package Install page select confirm to schedule the installation.

sect1.para: The Proxy pattern will be installed and the client will be upgraded to a &susemgrproxy;. You may then register your clients against the proxy using a bootstrap script as if it were a &susemgr; Server.

sect1.title: Running configure-proxy.sh
sect1.para: The configure-proxy.sh script will finalize the setup of your &susemgr; proxy.

On the proxy, log in as root and execute the interactive configure-proxy.sh script; answer questions about &susemgr; Parent, CA Chain, Proxy version, Trace back email, Use SSL, HTTP Proxy, and provide input for an SSL certificate. A &susemgr; Parent can be either another proxy server or a &susemgr; server. Configuration input for monitoring follows. Next steps are CA password, whether to create and populate the configuration channel, and the credentials of the &susemgr; server (user name and password).

If parts are missing, such as CA key and public certificate, the script prints commands that you must execute to integrate the needed files. When the mandatory files are copied, re-run configure-proxy.sh.
configure-proxy.sh activates services required by &susemgr; Proxy, such as squid, apache2, and jabberd.

To check the status of the proxy system and its clients, click the proxy system's details page on the &webui; (SystemsProxy, then the system name). Connection and Proxy subtabs display the respective status information.

sect1.title: Registering Clients via &susemgrproxy;
sect1.para: Registering clients via &susemgrproxy; is done almost the same way as registering clients directly with the &susemgr; server. The difference is that you create a bootstrap script on the &susemgrproxy; with a command-line tool. The bootstrap script then deploys all necessary information to the clients. The bootstrap script refers some parameters (such as activation keys or GPG keys) that depend on your specific setup. For background information, see the &mgrclientconfguide;.

step.para: Create a client activation key on the &susemgr; server using the WebUI. See:

On the proxy, execute the mgr-bootstrap command-line tool as &rootuser;. If needed, edit the resulting bootstrap script or optionally use the additional command-line switches to add data to your bootstrap script. To view available options type mgr-bootstrap --help from the command line:
Execute the bootstrap script on the clients as described in

sect1.para: The clients are registered with the &susemgrproxy; specified in the bootstrap script.

sect1.title: Migrating &susemgrproxy; 2.1 to &susemgrproxy; 3
sect1.para: The recommended order for migrations is to first migrate the server and then the proxies. Please note that a SUSE Manager proxy 2.1 cooperates just fine with a new SUSE Manager 3.

For the migration of the proxies there are two possible approaches: Existing SUSE Manager proxies may be auto-upgraded to version 3 by means of YaST auto-installation. Alternatively the proxies may be replaced by new ones. This section documents both approaches.

sect2.title: Replacing a &susemgrproxy;
sect2.para: A SUSE Manager Proxy is dumb in the sense that it does not contain any information about the clients which are connected to it. A SUSE Manager Proxy can therefore be replaced by a new one. Naturally the replacement proxy must have the same name and IP address as its predecessor.

step.para: To replace a SUSE Manager Proxy, delete the system from the SUSE Manager system list.
Shutdown the proxy and install the latest version.

Complete the registration steps described in this chapter to register your proxy normally. Once you have completed registering the new proxy with the server, utilizing the appropriate channels, and finally having run the configure-proxy.sh script, all clients formally connected via the older proxy will continue operating as before.

important.title: Proxy Installation and Client Connections
important.para: During the installation of the proxy, clients will not be able to reach the SUSE Manager server. After a SUSE Manager Proxy system has been deleted from the system list, all clients connected to this proxy will be (incorrectly) listed as directly connected to the &susemgr; server. After the first successful operation on a client such as execution of a remote command or installation of a package or patch this information will automatically be corrected. Note that this may take a few hours.

sect2.title: Upgrading a &susemgrproxy; from 2.1 - 3
sect2.para: In most situations upgrading the proxy will be your preferred solution as this retains all cached packages. Selecting this route saves time especially regarding setups with proxies connected to SUSE Manager server via low-bandwith links. This upgrade can be automated by using the YaST auto-installation feature. The following procedure demonstrates this.

step.para: Create an auto-installable distribution based on SLES 12 SP2. SUSE Manager Proxy 3 is based on SLES 12 SP2. Refer to the SUSE Manager Documentation on creating and auto-installable distribution.add link to auto-install section

To start the auto-installation on a proxy, some additional packages must be installed which are only available in the SUSE Manager Tools channel. These tools are not available for proxies as the system was shipped as an appliance in the past. To gain access to the required packages for use with proxies, the underlying SLES 11 SP3 channel (SLES11-SP3-SUSE-Manager-Tools) needs to be cloned and assigned to the to-be-upgraded proxies. After these steps have been completed, create an auto-installation profile.

note.title: remove_initrd_koan.sh
note.para: The purpose of this script is to act as a workaround for the following problem: During installation the initrd of the installation media (SLES12SP2) is in use. This initrd is rather large (around 50 MB), so there is not enough space left when the new kernel is being installed. Therefore this script deletes the initial ramdisk file once it has been booted. The partition of your boot partition might differ, so it should be explicitly specified in the autoinstall file.

sect2.para: During auto-installation this script attempts to delete the initial ramdisk file once it has booted. Your boot partition may differ, so ensure it is explicitly specified within the auto-install file.

If this step is bi-passed or mixed up (for example: specifying a wrong value) its fine. During installation of the new kernel, YaST will detect that there is not enough space available and will stop. You may switch to another console (there is a shell running on virtual console 2) and reclaim some disk space by issuing the following command:

One you have completed this step, switch back to the console where YaST is running (console 7) and click retry. Installation of the kernel will continue and succeed. The system will reboot, a few automated init scripts will run and the proxy will be upgraded to the &susemgr; 3 base SLES12SP2 and will be fully functional.
